Text: Prudential practice guides (PPGs) provide guidance on APRA’s view of sound practice in particular areas. PPGs frequently discuss statutory requirements from legislation, regulations or APRA’s prudential standards, but do not themselves create enforceable requirements. PPGs target areas where APRA continues to identify weaknesses as part of its ongoing supervisory activities, and do not seek to provide an all-encompassing framework, or to replace or endorse existing industry standards and guidelines.
Interpretation/Simplification: Prudential Practice Guides (PPGs) offer guidance on best practices and discuss existing regulations, but do not create new mandatory rules. They focus on common weaknesses identified by APRA and are not exhaustive frameworks.

Text: This PPG aims to outline prudent practices in the management of risks arising from lending secured by mortgages over residential properties, including owner-occupied and investment properties. It applies to authorised deposit-taking institutions (ADIs) as well as to other APRA-regulated institutions that may have exposures to residential mortgages.
Interpretation/Simplification: This guide focuses on best practices for managing risks associated with residential mortgage lending (both owner-occupied and investment properties). It is applicable to ADIs and other APRA-regulated entities with residential mortgage exposures.

Text: It should be read in conjunction with prudential standards for ADIs, including: • Prudential Standard APS 220 Credit Risk Management (APS 220); • Prudential Standard CPS 220 Risk Management (CPS 220); • Prudential Practice Guide CPG 220 Risk Management (CPG 220); and • Prudential Standard CPS 510 Governance (CPS 510).
Interpretation/Simplification: This PPG must be considered alongside existing APRA prudential standards for ADIs, specifically APS 220, CPS 220, CPG 220, and CPS 510, which cover credit risk, risk management, and governance.

Text: Subject to meeting APRA’s prudential requirements, and legislative and regulatory requirements governing consumer lending by ADIs and third parties acting on their behalf, an APRA-regulated institution has the flexibility to manage residential mortgage lending in a manner that is best suited to achieving its business objectives. Not all of the practices outlined in this PPG will be relevant for every institution and some aspects may vary depending upon the size, complexity and risk profile of the institution.
Interpretation/Simplification: Institutions can manage residential mortgage lending flexibly to meet business goals, provided they comply with APRA's prudential and legal requirements. The relevance of practices in this guide varies based on an institution's size, complexity, and risk profile.

Text: Lending secured by mortgages over residential property (residential mortgage lending) constitutes the largest credit exposure in the Australian banking system, and for many authorised deposit-taking institutions (ADIs) constitutes over half their total credit exposures. This concentration of exposure warrants ADIs paying particular attention to residential mortgage lending practices.
Interpretation/Simplification: Residential mortgage lending represents the largest credit exposure in Australia's banking system, often exceeding 50% of total credit exposures for ADIs. This high concentration necessitates careful attention to lending practices by ADIs.

Text: This prudential practice guide (PPG) summarises prudent lending practices in residential mortgage lending in Australia, including the need to address credit risk within the ADI’s risk management framework, sound loan origination criteria, appropriate security valuation practices, the management of hardship loans and a robust stress-testing framework. In developing this PPG, APRA has had regard to the Financial Stability Board’s (FSB) Principles for Sound Residential Mortgage Underwriting Practices1 (FSB principles), which sets out minimum underwriting (loan origination) standards that the FSB encourages supervisors to implement. Although the exact details may differ somewhat to reflect local conditions, APRA would expect a prudent ADI undertaking residential mortgage lending outside of Australia to apply lending standards and risk management practices that are similarly conservative to those outlined in this PPG.
Interpretation/Simplification: This PPG outlines best practices for residential mortgage lending in Australia, covering credit risk, loan origination, valuations, hardship loans, and stress testing, drawing on FSB principles. APRA expects ADIs operating internationally to adopt similarly conservative lending standards and risk management.

Text: APRA’s expectations of an ADI Board for residential mortgage lending
Interpretation/Simplification: This section details APRA's expectations for an ADI's Board of Directors concerning residential mortgage lending practices.

Text: Where residential mortgage lending forms a material proportion of an ADI’s lending portfolio and therefore a risk that may have a material impact on the ADI, APRA expects that the Board would take reasonable steps to satisfy itself as to the level of risk in the ADI’s residential mortgage lending portfolio and the effectiveness of its risk management framework.
Interpretation/Simplification: If residential mortgage lending is a significant part of the ADI's portfolio and poses material risk, the Board must take appropriate measures to understand the risk level and confirm the effectiveness of the risk management framework.

Text: specifically addressing residential mortgage lending in the ADI’s risk appetite, risk management strategy and business plans;
Interpretation/Simplification: The ADI's risk appetite statement, risk management strategy, and business plans must explicitly cover residential mortgage lending.

Text: seeking assurances from senior management that the approved risk appetite is communicated to relevant persons involved in residential mortgage lending and is appropriately reflected in the ADI’s policies and procedures;
Interpretation/Simplification: The Board must ensure that senior management confirms that the approved risk appetite is communicated to all relevant personnel involved in residential mortgage lending and is integrated into the ADI's policies and procedures.

Text: seeking assurances from senior management that there is a robust management information system in place that:
Interpretation/Simplification: The Board must obtain assurance from senior management that a robust management information system (MIS) is operational to support risk management.

Text: tracks material risks against risk appetite;
Interpretation/Simplification: The management information system (MIS) must be capable of monitoring significant risks and comparing them against the established risk appetite.

Text: provides periodic reporting on compliance with policies and procedures, reasons for significant breaches or material deviations and updates on actions being taken to rectify breaches or deviations;
Interpretation/Simplification: The MIS must generate regular reports on adherence to policies, explain major breaches or deviations, and provide updates on corrective actions implemented.

Text: provides accurate, timely and relevant information on the performance and risk profile of the residential mortgage lending portfolio.
Interpretation/Simplification: The MIS must deliver precise, current, and pertinent data regarding the performance and risk characteristics of the residential mortgage lending portfolio.

Sub-section: Risk appetite including residential mortgage lending
Text: Risk appetite including residential mortgage lending
Interpretation/Simplification: This sub-section discusses how residential mortgage lending should be integrated into the institution's overall risk appetite.

Sub-section: Risk appetite including residential mortgage lending
Text: The overarching risk appetite statement required under CPS 220 would typically include an expression of the level of credit risk an ADI is willing to accept. Such a statement would be expected to adopt a forward-looking view of the ADI’s credit risk profile and align with its business plan and risk management strategy.
Interpretation/Simplification: The main risk appetite statement, mandated by CPS 220, should define the acceptable level of credit risk, anticipate future credit risk, and align with the ADI’s business plans and risk management strategy.

Sub-section: Risk appetite including residential mortgage lending
Text: Consistent with Prudential Standard CPS 220 Risk Management (CPS 220), where residential mortgage lending forms a material proportion of an ADI’s lending portfolio and therefore represents a risk that may have a material impact on the ADI, it would be prudent for the Board of directors (the Board) and senior management to specifically address residential mortgage lending in its risk management framework, in particular in the risk appetite statement, risk management strategy and business plans.
Interpretation/Simplification: In line with CPS 220, if residential mortgage lending is a significant risk exposure, the Board and senior management should explicitly incorporate it into their risk management framework, especially within the risk appetite statement, risk management strategy, and business plans.

Text: Where residential mortgage lending forms a material proportion of an ADI’s lending portfolio and therefore represents a risk that may have a material impact on the ADI, the accepted level of credit risk would be expected to specifically address the risk in the residential mortgage portfolio. Further, in order to assist senior management and lending staff to operate within the accepted level of credit risk, quantifiable risk limits would be set for various aspects of the residential mortgage portfolio. When setting risk limits for the residential mortgage portfolio, a prudent ADI would consider the following areas:
Interpretation/Simplification: If residential mortgage lending is a significant part of the ADI's business, credit risk assessments must specifically cover this. Quantifiable risk limits should be established to guide senior management and lending staff.

Text: loans with differing risk profiles (e.g. interest-only loans, owner-occupied, investment property, reverse mortgages, home equity lines-of-credit (HELOCs), foreign currency loans and loans with non-standard/alternative documentation);
Interpretation/Simplification: When setting mortgage risk limits, consider the varied risk profiles of different loan types (e.g., interest-only, investment, HELOCs, non-standard documentation).

Text: loans originated through various channels (e.g. mobile lenders, brokers, branches and online);
Interpretation/Simplification: When setting mortgage risk limits, consider risks arising from different loan origination channels (e.g., mobile lenders, brokers, online platforms).

Text: geographic concentrations;
Interpretation/Simplification: When setting mortgage risk limits, consider the geographic concentration of loans.

Text: serviceability criteria (e.g. limits on loan size relative to income, (stressed) mortgage repayments to income, net income surplus and other debt servicing measures);
Interpretation/Simplification: When setting mortgage risk limits, include serviceability criteria such as loan size relative to income and stressed repayment-to-income ratios.

Text: loan-to-valuation ratios (LVRs), including limits on high LVR loans for new originations and for the overall portfolio;
Interpretation/Simplification: When setting mortgage risk limits, establish limits on loan-to-valuation ratios (LVRs), especially for high LVR loans, both for new loans and the entire portfolio.

Text: use of lenders mortgage insurance (LMI) and associated concentration risks;
Interpretation/Simplification: When setting mortgage risk limits, consider the use of Lenders Mortgage Insurance (LMI) and any associated concentration risks.

Text: special circumstance loans, such as reliance on guarantors, loans to retired or soon-to–be-retired persons, loans to non-residents, loans with non-typical features such as trusts or self-managed superannuation funds (SMSFs);
Interpretation/Simplification: When setting mortgage risk limits, take into account special circumstance loans, including those with guarantors, to retirees, non-residents, or those involving trusts/SMSFs.

Text: frequency and types of overrides to lending policies, guidelines and loan origination standards;
Interpretation/Simplification: When setting mortgage risk limits, monitor and consider the frequency and types of overrides applied to lending policies and origination standards.

Text: maximum expected or tolerable portfolio default, arrears and write-off rates; and
Interpretation/Simplification: When setting mortgage risk limits, define the maximum acceptable portfolio default, arrears, and write-off rates.

Text: non-lending losses such as operational breakdowns or adverse reputational events related to consumer lending practices.
Interpretation/Simplification: When setting mortgage risk limits, consider potential non-lending losses, such as those from operational failures or negative reputational events linked to consumer lending.

Text: Good practice would be for the risk management framework to clearly specify whether particular risk limits are ‘hard’ limits, where any breach is escalated for action as soon as practicable, or ‘soft’ limits, where occasional or temporary breaches are tolerated.
Interpretation/Simplification: The risk management framework should clearly define whether risk limits are 'hard' (requiring immediate escalation for breaches) or 'soft' (allowing occasional or temporary breaches).

Text: In keeping with good practice, an ADI would balance the need to regularly review its risk appetite and risk limits in relation to residential mortgage lending, with the need to avoid too-frequent and disruptive change. APRA would be concerned if risk limits were frequently redefined in a manner that leads to obscured limit breaches or to greater risk-taking outside the ADI’s overall risk appetite. This could include, for example, changing between portfolio and origination limit measures, or between including and excluding capitalised LMI premiums in risk limits.
Interpretation/Simplification: ADIs must regularly review their risk appetite and limits for residential mortgage lending, but avoid frequent, disruptive changes or changes that obscure breaches or promote excessive risk-taking.

Text: Consistent with CPS 220, an ADI would have policies and procedures for identifying, measuring, monitoring and controlling material risks in the residential mortgage lending portfolio.
Interpretation/Simplification: In line with CPS 220, ADIs must establish policies and procedures to identify, measure, monitor, and control significant risks within their residential mortgage lending portfolio.

Text: Typically, senior management is responsible for monitoring compliance with material policies, procedures and risk limits and reporting material breaches or overrides to the Board. Further, where risk limits are routinely breached or policies and procedures overridden, senior management and the Board could consider whether this is indicative of a less prudent lending culture than that reflected in its risk appetite and what steps could be necessary to remedy any identified deficiency.
Interpretation/Simplification: Senior management is responsible for monitoring compliance with policies and risk limits, and for reporting significant breaches or overrides to the Board. Frequent breaches should prompt senior management and the Board to assess the lending culture and take corrective actions.

Text: In order to establish robust oversight, the Board and senior management would receive regular, concise and meaningful assessment of actual risks relative to the ADI’s risk appetite and of the operation and effectiveness of internal controls. The information would be provided in a timely manner to facilitate early corrective action.
Interpretation/Simplification: For effective oversight, the Board and senior management must receive regular, clear, and relevant assessments of actual risks against the ADI's risk appetite, as well as the effectiveness of internal controls. This information should be provided promptly to allow for early corrective action.

Text: A prudent ADI would have controls in relation to its residential mortgage portfolio that have appropriate regard to the level of risk within the portfolio. Portfolios that have higher inherent risk, for example where the portfolio is usually operating at the higher end of risk limits, would typically be accompanied by stronger controls, including:
Interpretation/Simplification: An ADI must implement controls for its residential mortgage portfolio that are proportionate to its risk level. Higher-risk portfolios require stronger controls.

Text: increased senior management oversight;
Interpretation/Simplification: Higher risk mortgage portfolios require increased oversight from senior management.

Text: increased monitoring and more granular reporting to the Board and senior management;
Interpretation/Simplification: For higher risk mortgage portfolios, implement more detailed monitoring and reporting to the Board and senior management.

Text: increased level and frequency of reviews by the risk management function;
Interpretation/Simplification: The risk management function should conduct more frequent and in-depth reviews of higher risk mortgage portfolios.

Text: increased level of internal audit;
Interpretation/Simplification: For higher risk mortgage portfolios, increase the level and scope of internal audits.

Text: stronger default management and collection capabilities; and
Interpretation/Simplification: Enhance default management and collection capabilities for higher risk mortgage portfolios.

Text: provisioning and capital levels reflective of the risk of the portfolio.
Interpretation/Simplification: Ensure provisioning and capital levels accurately reflect the inherent risks of the mortgage portfolio.

Text: Consistent with CPS 220, the aspects of the risk management framework that apply to the residential mortgage lending portfolio would be subject to a comprehensive review by an operationally independent and competent person at least every three years. The person would report the results of reviews to the Board, providing an independent and objective evaluation of the appropriateness, adequacy and effectiveness of the risk management framework with respect to the portfolio.
Compliance To be Done: Ensure a comprehensive independent review of the residential mortgage lending risk management framework every three years and report findings to the Board.
Interpretation/Simplification: At least every three years, an independent and qualified individual must conduct a thorough review of the mortgage lending risk management framework and present an objective evaluation to the Board.

Text: Failure to meet responsible lending conduct obligations, such as the requirement to make reasonable inquiries about the borrower’s requirements and objectives, or failure to document these enquiries, can expose an ADI to potentially significant risks. A prudent ADI would conduct a periodic assessment of compliance with responsible lending conduct obligations to ensure it does not expose itself to significant financial loss.
Interpretation/Simplification: ADIs must regularly assess their compliance with responsible lending obligations, including making and documenting reasonable inquiries about borrowers' needs, to avoid significant financial risks.

Text: It would be prudent for an ADI with material exposure to residential mortgage lending to invest in management information systems that allow for appropriate assessment of residential mortgage lending risk exposures. Such a system would typically capture a range of risk metrics related to individual loans at the point of application and throughout the life of the loan.2
Interpretation/Simplification: ADIs with significant residential mortgage lending exposure should invest in Management Information Systems (MIS) capable of assessing risks, capturing individual loan metrics from application through to maturity.

Text: Further, a prudent ADI would have analytical capability that allows it to monitor, analyse and report key metrics against risk appetite and to assess the residential mortgage portfolio at both the individual loan level and portfolio level. The data, when collectively presented to the Board and senior management, would enable an accurate and meaningful assessment of the residential mortgage portfolio. A history of low defaults does not justify under-investment in management information systems.
Interpretation/Simplification: ADIs need analytical tools to monitor, analyze, and report key mortgage metrics against risk appetite at both individual loan and portfolio levels. This data must be presented to the Board and senior management for accurate assessment; past low defaults do not excuse poor MIS investment.

Text: A robust management information system would be able to provide good quality information on residential mortgage lending risks. This would typically include:
Interpretation/Simplification: A strong Management Information System (MIS) should deliver high-quality data on residential mortgage lending risks, covering various key areas.

Text: the composition and quality of the residential mortgage lending portfolio, e.g. by type of customer (first home buyer, owner-occupied, investment etc), product line, distribution channel, loan vintage, geographic concentration, LVR bands at origination, loans on the watch list and impaired;
Interpretation/Simplification: The MIS must report on the composition and quality of the mortgage portfolio, categorized by customer type, product, channel, vintage, geography, LVR, and status (watchlist/impaired).

Text: portfolio performance reporting, including trend analysis, peer comparisons where possible, other risk-adjusted profitability and economic capital measures and results from stress tests;
Interpretation/Simplification: The MIS must provide portfolio performance reports including trend analysis, peer comparisons (if available), risk-adjusted profitability, economic capital metrics, and stress test results.

Text: compliance against risk limits and trigger levels at which action is required;
Interpretation/Simplification: The MIS must report on compliance against established risk limits and any trigger levels that necessitate action.

Text: reports on broker relationships and performance;
Interpretation/Simplification: The MIS must generate reports detailing broker relationships and their performance.

Text: exception reporting including overrides, key drivers for overrides and delinquency performance for loans approved by override;
Interpretation/Simplification: The MIS must provide exception reports that detail overrides, their key drivers, and the delinquency performance of loans approved through overrides.

Text: reports on loan breaches and other issues arising from annual reviews;
Interpretation/Simplification: The MIS must provide reports on loan breaches and any other issues identified during annual reviews.

Text: prepayment rates and mortgage prepayment buffers;
Interpretation/Simplification: The MIS must track and report on mortgage prepayment rates and prepayment buffers.

Text: serviceability buffers including trends, performance, recent changes to buffers and adjustments and rationale for changes;
Interpretation/Simplification: The MIS must report on serviceability buffers, including trends, performance, recent changes, adjustments made, and the reasoning behind those changes.

Text: missed payments, hardship concessions and restructurings, cure rates and 30-, 60- and 90- days arrears levels across, for example, different segments of the portfolio, loan vintage, geographic region, borrower type, distribution channel and product type;
Interpretation/Simplification: The MIS must report on missed payments, hardship concessions, restructurings, cure rates, and 30/60/90-day arrears levels, segmented by portfolio characteristics like vintage, geography, borrower type, channel, and product.

Text: changes to valuation methodologies, types and location of collateral held and analysis relating to any current or expected changes in collateral values;
Interpretation/Simplification: The MIS must track changes in valuation methodologies, types and locations of collateral, and provide analysis on current or anticipated changes in collateral values.

Text: findings from valuer reviews or other hindsight reviews undertaken by the ADI;
Interpretation/Simplification: The MIS must include findings from valuer reviews and other post-loan performance reviews conducted by the ADI.

Text: reporting against key metrics to measure collections performance;
Interpretation/Simplification: The MIS must provide reports based on key metrics for measuring collections performance.

Text: tracking of loans insured by LMI providers, including claims made and adverse findings by such providers;
Interpretation/Simplification: The MIS must track loans insured by LMI providers, including any claims made and adverse findings reported by those providers.

Text: provisioning trends and write-offs;
Interpretation/Simplification: The MIS must report on provisioning trends and loan write-offs.

Text: internal and external audit findings and tracking of unresolved issues and closure;
Interpretation/Simplification: The MIS must track internal and external audit findings, unresolved issues, and their closure status.

Text: issues of contention with third-parties including service providers, valuation firms, etc; and
Interpretation/Simplification: The MIS must report on any contentious issues with third parties, such as service providers or valuation firms.

Text: risk drivers and other components that form part of scorecard or models used for loan origination as well as risk indicators for new lending.
Interpretation/Simplification: The MIS must include information on risk drivers and components of scorecards/models used for loan origination, as well as risk indicators for new lending.

Text: Prudential Standard CPS 510 Governance (CPS 510) requires the Board-approved ADI remuneration policy to be aligned with prudent risk-taking. CPS 510 requires the remuneration policy to apply to responsible persons, risk and financial control personnel and all other persons whose activities may affect the financial soundness of the regulated institution.3 Where the residential mortgage lending portfolio is material, a prudent ADI would apply its remuneration policy to the persons involved in residential mortgage lending. This would include remuneration of third parties, particularly mortgage broker firms, when they are responsible for origination of a material proportion of the residential mortgage loan portfolio. For the avoidance of doubt, the ADI remuneration policy is intended to capture an ADI’s engagement with its brokers, not how a broking firm pays its staff. Alternatively, the ADI may address such remuneration arrangements within its risk management framework with appropriate senior management or Board oversight.
Interpretation/Simplification: The ADI's Board-approved remuneration policy must align with prudent risk-taking (per CPS 510) and apply to all staff impacting financial soundness. If residential mortgage lending is material, this policy must extend to all involved, including third-party mortgage brokers, focusing on the ADI's engagement with them, not their internal pay structure. These arrangements can also be managed via the risk management framework.

Text: In Australia, it is standard market practice to pay brokers either an upfront commission or a trailing commission, or both. A prudent approach to the use of third parties for residential mortgage lending would include appropriate measures to ensure that commission-based compensation does not create adverse incentives. Such measures would include consideration of appropriate clawback provisions and ensure that incentive arrangements discourage conflicts of interests and inappropriate behaviour.
Interpretation/Simplification: When engaging third-party mortgage brokers (who typically receive upfront or trailing commissions), ADIs must implement measures, like clawback provisions, to prevent commission structures from creating incentives for conflicts of interest or inappropriate behavior.

Text: Regardless of the commission structure, a prudent ADI would recognise the incentives and potential risks inherent in its broker remuneration structure. It would have in place appropriate monitoring and controls to guard against incentives to pursue loans with inadequate or false verification, marginal serviceability, excessive leverage or unsuitable terms for a borrower.
Interpretation/Simplification: ADIs must acknowledge the risks in their broker remuneration structures and implement robust monitoring and controls to prevent brokers from originating loans with inadequate verification, marginal serviceability, excessive leverage, or unsuitable terms for borrowers.

Text: A prudent ADI relying on brokers to originate a material proportion of its residential mortgage portfolio would closely monitor performance at the broker firm or, where relevant, the individual broker level. Where loans originated by a broker or broker firm have unexpectedly elevated levels of loan defaults, or materially deficient loan documentation and processing, a prudent ADI would take measures to address such matters including restricting or terminating such relationships.
Interpretation/Simplification: If an ADI relies significantly on brokers for mortgage origination, it must closely monitor their performance. If a broker or firm consistently originates loans with high defaults or poor documentation, the ADI must take corrective action, potentially restricting or ending the relationship.

Text: Residential mortgage lending risks change over time. A prudent ADI would have regard to the impact on the portfolio of varying conditions, such as low or recently changed interest rates, rapid house price increases or decreases and large changes in housing supply or demand in particular markets. Changes to consumer credit conduct obligations, including responsible lending obligations, also need to be considered.
Interpretation/Simplification: ADIs must continuously monitor and assess the impact of evolving market conditions (e.g., interest rates, house prices, supply/demand) and changes in consumer credit and responsible lending obligations on their residential mortgage portfolio.

Text: When an ADI is increasing its residential mortgage lending rapidly or at a rate materially faster than its competitors, either across the portfolio or in particular segments or geographical areas, a prudent Board would seek explanation as to why this is the case. Rapid relative growth could be due to an unintended deterioration in the ADI’s loan origination practices, in which case APRA expects that an ADI’s risk management framework would facilitate rapid and effective measures to mitigate any consequences.
Interpretation/Simplification: If an ADI's mortgage lending grows significantly faster than competitors, the Board must seek an explanation. The risk management framework should facilitate swift and effective mitigation if this growth stems from deteriorating origination practices.

Text: ADIs typically use various direct and indirect origination channels to source mortgage loans, for example, branches, telephone, brokers and online. A prudent ADI would recognise and address the risks arising from different origination channels in its risk management framework. An ADI would typically exercise a higher level of diligence when the credit approval decision is made distant from the location of the borrower or the underlying collateral. A degree of local knowledge (e.g. local house price levels, levels of available stock, local employment and competition issues) by assessors can be useful. In APRA’s experience, ADIs that extend loans away from their core geographic market tend to be more reliant on third-party originators. If not closely monitored, this reliance can potentially lead to additional risk and give rise to higher levels of exposure that may be outside an ADI’s risk appetite.
Interpretation/Simplification: ADIs must identify and manage risks across all loan origination channels. Higher diligence is required for remote credit approvals, with local knowledge being beneficial. Reliance on third-party originators in distant markets needs close monitoring to prevent exposure beyond risk appetite.

Text: Where there are material changes to distribution channels, a robust risk management framework would include the need to assess changes to an ADI’s risk profile and address this risk.
Interpretation/Simplification: When significant changes occur in loan distribution channels, the risk management framework must assess and address any resulting changes to the ADI's risk profile.

Text: Accurately assessing a borrower’s ability to service and ultimately to repay a loan without undue hardship, including under periods of economic stress, is an inherent component of sound credit risk management, particularly for residential mortgage lending. An ADI’s serviceability tests are used to determine whether the borrower can afford the ongoing servicing and repayment costs of the loan for which they have applied. APRA expects an ADI to undertake a new serviceability assessment whenever there are material changes to the current or originally approved loan conditions. Such changes would include a change of repayment basis from principal and interest to interest-only, or the extension of an existing interest-only period. A change from a fixed-rate basis to a floating-rate basis (or vice versa), or an extension in the tenor of the loan are other examples of material changes. A new serviceability assessment would be appropriate for any change that increases the total repayments over the life of the loan, even when immediate periodic repayments are lower than under the previous loan conditions.
Interpretation/Simplification: ADIs must accurately assess a borrower's ability to repay a loan, especially under economic stress. A new serviceability assessment is required for any material changes to loan conditions, such as changes in repayment basis, interest-only periods, interest rate type, loan tenor, or any change increasing total lifetime repayments, even if immediate payments decrease.

Text: Sound loan origination practices are necessary for prudent residential mortgage lending whether the loans are originated directly by an ADI or are sourced from other distribution channels. As well as considering individual loans, effective risk management requires a portfolio view of originations.
Interpretation/Simplification: Prudent residential mortgage lending demands sound origination practices, irrespective of the channel. Effective risk management requires both individual loan and portfolio-level assessment of originations.

Text: In particular, a prudent ADI would have appropriate procedures in place to verify the accuracy and completeness of the information provided.
Interpretation/Simplification: A bank must have proper processes to check if the information it receives is accurate and complete.

Text: Good practice would be for an ADI, rather than a third party, to perform income verification.
Interpretation/Simplification: Ideally, the bank should verify income itself, not outsource it to a third party.

Text: However, if a third party does perform such a role, an ADI would be expected to implement appropriate oversight processes covering income verification.
Interpretation/Simplification: If a third party does income verification, the bank must have suitable oversight processes in place for it.

Text: Such oversight would extend to third parties that are granted any form of DLA, even if the ability to approve transactions is within policy limits.
Interpretation/Simplification: This oversight applies even to third parties with limited delegated loan approval authority.

Text: An ADI would also monitor and test the integrity of the third-party approval and verification processes periodically, either directly or through operationally independent persons.
Interpretation/Simplification: The bank must regularly monitor and test the reliability of third-party approval and verification processes, either directly or through independent personnel.

Text: Consistent with CPS 231, a prudent ADI would ensure that its arrangements with third-party residential mortgage loan originators allow for timely cessation of such arrangements should the ADI form the view that it is no longer able to place reliance on the third party.
Interpretation/Simplification: Following CPS 231, the bank's agreements with third-party mortgage originators must allow it to quickly end the relationship if it loses trust in the third party.

Text: Some ADIs use rules-based scorecards or quantitative models in the residential mortgage loan evaluation process.
Interpretation/Simplification: Banks sometimes use automated scorecards or models to assess residential mortgage loan applications.

Text: In such cases, good practice would include close oversight and governance of the credit scoring processes.
Interpretation/Simplification: If credit scorecards are used, there must be strong supervision and management of these processes.

Text: Where decisions suggested by a scorecard are overridden, it is good practice to document the reasons for the override.
Interpretation/Simplification: If a loan decision from a scorecard is changed, the reasons for that change must be recorded.

Text: Scorecards or models would be subject to regular monitoring and validation to ensure that they remain effective over time.
Interpretation/Simplification: Credit scorecards and models must be regularly monitored and validated to ensure they continue to work correctly.

Text: A prudent ADI would develop and document an effective governance framework and benchmarks to assess the performance of a scorecard or model, which would be overseen by the ADI’s senior management.
Interpretation/Simplification: The bank must create and document a governance framework with benchmarks to evaluate the performance of scorecards/models, with senior management oversight.

Text: It would be good practice for an ADI using scorecards or similar models to develop its own tests, using internal or external expertise as appropriate.
Interpretation/Simplification: Banks using scorecards or models should develop their own tests for them, using internal staff or outside experts as needed.

Text: Reliance upon the model or scorecard vendor to provide model validation services can create a material conflict of interest, which an ADI would need to manage.
Interpretation/Simplification: Using the same vendor for model development and validation creates a conflict of interest that the bank must manage.

Text: In such cases, it would be prudent to seek an independent third-party assessor to mitigate the potential conflict of interest.
Interpretation/Simplification: To reduce conflict of interest, it's wise to hire an independent third party to assess the model.

Text: Borrowers may have legitimate reasons to prefer interest-only loans in some circumstances, such as for repayment flexibility or tax reasons.
Interpretation/Simplification: Explains that borrowers may choose interest-only loans for reasons like flexible payments or tax benefits.

Text: However, interest-only loans may carry higher credit risk in some cases, and may not be appropriate for all borrowers.
Interpretation/Simplification: Highlights that interest-only loans can be riskier and are not suitable for every borrower.

Text: This should be reflected in the ADI’s risk management framework, including its risk appetite statement, and also in the ADI’s responsible lending compliance program.
Interpretation/Simplification: The risks of interest-only loans must be incorporated into the bank's risk management framework, risk appetite, and responsible lending program.

Text: APRA expects that an ADI would only approve interest-only loans for owner-occupiers where there is a sound and documented economic basis for such an arrangement and not based on inability to service a loan on a principal and interest basis.
Interpretation/Simplification: Banks should only approve interest-only loans for owner-occupiers if there's a strong, documented financial reason, not merely because they can't afford principal and interest payments.

Text: APRA expects interest-only periods offered on residential mortgage loans to be of limited duration, particularly for owner-occupiers.
Interpretation/Simplification: The interest-only period for residential mortgages, especially for owner-occupiers, should be short.

Text: As noted above, a prudent serviceability assessment would incorporate the borrower’s ability to repay principal and interest over the actual repayment period.
Interpretation/Simplification: Loan affordability assessments must consider the borrower's ability to repay both principal and interest over the full loan term.

Text: In APRA’s view, it is not prudent to extend foreign currency-denominated loans against domestic currency (e.g. Australian dollar) income streams or against domestic currency collateral.
Interpretation/Simplification: It is not advisable to offer foreign currency loans if the borrower's income or collateral is in local currency.

Text: However, an ADI may occasionally extend a foreign-currency loan to a borrower with a foreign currency-denominated income stream.
Interpretation/Simplification: A bank may provide a foreign currency loan if the borrower's income is also in that foreign currency.

Text: In such cases, the ADI could face additional challenges in validating offshore income streams.
Interpretation/Simplification: Verifying overseas income for foreign currency loans can be challenging for the bank.

Text: Loans extended on such a basis require substantial loan origination expertise.
Interpretation/Simplification: Banks need considerable expertise to originate foreign currency loans.

Text: It would also be good practice to discount offshore income in assessing a borrower’s loan servicing capacity.
Interpretation/Simplification: When assessing a borrower's ability to repay, it's good practice to apply a discount to offshore income.

Text: Loans with non-standard/alternative documentation can involve circumstances where the borrower is self-employed or has an uncertain income stream and is unable to provide standard documentation that enables easy verification of income.
Interpretation/Simplification: Describes loans where borrowers (e.g., self-employed) cannot provide standard income verification documents due to their situation.

Text: Good practice is to ensure that a loan with non-standard/alternative documentation is warranted due to the borrower’s situation rather than reluctance by the borrower to provide income documentation.
Interpretation/Simplification: Verify that non-standard documentation is truly needed because of the borrower's circumstances, not just because they are unwilling to provide standard documents.

Text: It is not good practice to underwrite loans on limited verification of a borrower’s income where full verification is reasonably available.
Interpretation/Simplification: Do not approve loans with minimal income checks if complete verification can reasonably be obtained.

Text: Where a borrower is unable to provide standard documentation, such as pay slips, an ADI would usually seek alternative documentation such as extensive cash flow history through bank statements, business activity statements, recent tax assessment notices or third-party confirmations from accountants or other professionals.
Interpretation/Simplification: If standard income documents like payslips are unavailable, the bank should request alternative proof, such as bank statements, tax notices, or professional confirmations.

Text: APRA expects that an ADI will recognise, in its risk appetite, portfolio limits for loans that may be more vulnerable to serviceability stress and possible material decreases in property value in a housing market downturn, and could therefore generate higher losses.
Interpretation/Simplification: The bank must set portfolio limits within its risk appetite for loans that are susceptible to repayment difficulties or property value drops, which could lead to greater losses.

Text: In assessing serviceability, a prudent ADI would seek to address any increased risk through appropriate pricing and significantly lower LVRs.
Interpretation/Simplification: When checking loan affordability, the bank should manage higher risks by adjusting pricing and requiring lower Loan-to-Value Ratios (LVRs).

Text: Reverse mortgage loans give rise to unique operational, legal and reputational risks, including in relation to consumer protection laws, which could affect loan enforceability.
Interpretation/Simplification: Reverse mortgages carry distinct operational, legal, and reputational risks, including consumer protection issues, which may impact the loan's enforceability.

Text: An ADI undertaking such lending would need to take appropriate measures to address these risks.
Interpretation/Simplification: Banks offering reverse mortgages must implement suitable measures to manage their unique risks.

Text: Such measures could, amongst others, include:
Interpretation/Simplification: Lists potential measures to manage reverse mortgage risks.

Text: assessment of the need for actuarial advice;
Interpretation/Simplification: The bank must assess whether actuarial advice is required for reverse mortgages.

Text: LVR caps related to the age of the borrower;
Interpretation/Simplification: Implement limits on Loan-to-Value Ratios (LVRs) for reverse mortgages, linked to the borrower's age.

Text: documented procedures applicable to the regular revaluation of properties underpinning reverse mortgages;
Interpretation/Simplification: Maintain written procedures for the regular revaluation of properties used as collateral for reverse mortgages.

Text: cautioning borrowers against waiving independent legal and financial advice; and
Interpretation/Simplification: Advise borrowers not to decline independent legal and financial advice.

Text: higher levels of controls and monitoring when marketing such loans through third-party channels.
Interpretation/Simplification: Apply stricter controls and monitoring when reverse mortgages are marketed through third parties.

Text: The revolving nature of home equity lines-of-credit loans may increase the risk of outstanding balances at default.
Interpretation/Simplification: The flexible nature of HELOCs can lead to higher outstanding debt if the borrower defaults.

Text: As a generalisation, HELOCs can result in different delinquency and default outcomes compared to traditional principal and interest products.
Interpretation/Simplification: HELOCs may show different patterns of late payments and defaults compared to standard principal and interest loans.

Text: A prudent ADI would establish checks and limits for such loans as part of its risk appetite statement.
Interpretation/Simplification: The bank must define controls and limits for Home Equity Lines of Credit (HELOCs) within its risk appetite statement.

Text: Examples include portfolio limits and limits on the non-amortising portion of such loans.
Interpretation/Simplification: These limits can include overall portfolio caps and restrictions on the part of the loan that does not reduce principal.

Text: Some ADIs provide loans to property held in SMSFs.
Interpretation/Simplification: Some banks offer loans for properties held by Self-Managed Superannuation Funds (SMSFs).

Text: The nature of loans to SMSFs gives rise to unique operational, legal and reputational risks that differ from those of a traditional mortgage loan.
Interpretation/Simplification: SMSF loans carry distinct operational, legal, and reputational risks compared to standard mortgages.

Text: Legal recourse in the event of default may differ from a standard mortgage, even with guarantees in place from other parties.
Interpretation/Simplification: The legal options for recovering funds in an SMSF loan default might be different from a standard mortgage, even with guarantees.

Text: Customer objectives and suitability may be more difficult to determine.
Interpretation/Simplification: It can be harder to understand and assess if an SMSF loan is suitable for the customer's objectives.

Text: In performing a serviceability assessment, ADIs would need to consider what regular income, subject to haircuts as discussed above, is available to service the loan and what expenses should be reflected in addition to the loan servicing.
Interpretation/Simplification: When assessing affordability for SMSF loans, banks must consider reliable income (after deductions) available for the loan and all other expenses.

Text: APRA expects that a prudent ADI would identify the additional risks relevant to this type of lending and implement loan application assessment processes and criteria that adequately reflect these risks.
Interpretation/Simplification: The bank must identify the unique risks of SMSF lending and incorporate them into its loan application and assessment processes.

Text: APRA also expects that a decision to undertake lending to SMSFs would be approved by the ADI at an appropriate governance forum and explicitly incorporated into the ADI’s policy framework.
Interpretation/Simplification: Any decision to offer SMSF loans must be approved by the bank's governance body (e.g., Board) and formally added to its policy framework.

Text: Techniques such as desk-top assessments, kerb-side assessment, automated valuation methods (AVMs) and reviews of contracts of sale are all acceptable valuation assessments, in the appropriate context.
Interpretation/Simplification: Describes various acceptable methods for property valuation, depending on the situation.

Text: As the risk associated with collateral increases, or the coverage of a given loan by collateral decreases, the need for specialist valuation also increases.
Interpretation/Simplification: When collateral risk rises or loan coverage by collateral falls, a more specialized valuation is required.

Text: A prudent ADI contemplating the use of alternative valuation methods such as AVMs would subject proposals to thorough analysis and develop a risk management capability that includes:
Interpretation/Simplification: A bank considering AVMs must thoroughly analyze them and build risk management capabilities, encompassing the following points.

Text: a hierarchy of acceptable methods of determining value that is appropriate to the level of risk;
Interpretation/Simplification: Establish a ranked list of acceptable valuation methods suitable for different risk levels.

Text: analysis of the strengths and weaknesses of the relevant approaches/models being considered, including an understanding of the methodologies used, sources of data employed and how the service provider may be able to assist in re-engineering the ADI’s processes;
Interpretation/Simplification: Analyze the pros and cons of valuation models, including their methods, data sources, and how providers can help improve the bank's processes.

Text: details of any back-testing of a statistically random sample of AVMs and desk-top assessments or auditing arrangements undertaken by the service provider;
Interpretation/Simplification: Obtain details of any back-testing or auditing of AVMs and desk-top assessments performed by the service provider.

Text: clarity of the output to be provided and how it would be integrated with the ADI’s processes;
Interpretation/Simplification: Ensure the valuation output is clear and can be properly integrated into the bank's systems.

Text: ongoing monitoring of tools used, processes that capture evidence of action taken when values are deemed to be unreliable and periodic back-testing undertaken by the ADI to independently validate reliability of outcomes; and
Interpretation/Simplification: Continuously monitor valuation tools, record actions taken when values are unreliable, and perform regular independent back-testing to confirm reliability.

Text: appropriate training for staff on operational requirements.
Interpretation/Simplification: Provide staff with proper training on operational requirements related to valuation tools and processes.

Text: Where an ADI relies on a panel of approved valuation professionals, sound credit risk management practice would provide for the panel to be periodically reviewed by senior risk management staff of the ADI.
Interpretation/Simplification: If the bank uses a panel of approved valuers, senior risk management must review this panel regularly.

Text: Valuer selection would be conducted by the ADI’s risk management area, rather than sales staff, and the involvement of ADI sales or product staff in panel management would be minimal.
Interpretation/Simplification: Valuer selection should be done by risk management, not sales staff, and sales/product staff involvement in managing the valuer panel should be minimal.

Text: An ADI is required to have regard to the requirements governing security valuation practices, including valuation of security in the form of property, as detailed in Attachment A of Prudential Standard APS 220 Credit Risk Management (APS 220).
Interpretation/Simplification: The bank must comply with security valuation requirements, especially for property, as detailed in Attachment A of Prudential Standard APS 220.

Text: Sound risk management practices would include valuation reports prepared with professional skill and diligence, valuers selected on the basis of appropriate professional qualifications and maintaining comprehensive valuation documentation for the term of the loan.
Interpretation/Simplification: Good risk management requires professional and diligent valuation reports, qualified valuers, and comprehensive valuation records kept for the loan's duration.

Text: The scope and extent of a valuation report would be commensurate with the property value and inherent risks.
Interpretation/Simplification: The detail in a valuation report should match the property's value and its associated risks.

Text: Attempts by an ADI or third-party lending staff to pressure valuers to over-value properties are an indicator of poor practice and improper behaviour.
Interpretation/Simplification: It is unacceptable for bank staff or third parties to pressure valuers into inflating property values.

Text: A robust risk management framework would capture such instances, prompting appropriate investigation and swift and appropriate action where necessary.
Interpretation/Simplification: The bank's risk framework must detect such pressure tactics, leading to investigation and quick, suitable corrective action.

Text: The valuation of underlying collateral can be undertaken in a range of ways. A full on-site valuation is good practice, although APRA acknowledges the benefit of tailoring an ADI’s valuation policy to its circumstances.
Interpretation/Simplification: Explains that collateral valuation can be done in various ways, with on-site valuation being good practice, but policies can be tailored.

Text: APRA expects that an ADI will document its valuation policy.
Interpretation/Simplification: The bank must formally document its policy for how it values collateral.

Text: The valuation management process itself may be outsourced to third parties.
Interpretation/Simplification: The management of valuation processes can be outsourced to external parties.

Text: When the valuation management is outsourced, the oversight and control would be retained by the ADI’s credit risk management.
Interpretation/Simplification: If valuation management is outsourced, the bank's credit risk management department must still maintain oversight and control.

Text: For example, it is good practice for any override of valuation requirements to be limited to senior credit risk management of the ADI.
Interpretation/Simplification: Only senior credit risk management should have the authority to override valuation requirements.

Text: Good practice would be to ensure that claims against collateral are legally enforceable and could be realised in a reasonable period of time if necessary.
Interpretation/Simplification: Ensure that the bank can legally claim and quickly recover collateral if required.

Text: This would include the ADI confirming that:
Interpretation/Simplification: The bank needs to confirm the following points regarding collateral.

Text: the borrower has, or will have when the loan is extended, a clear title to the property;
Interpretation/Simplification: Confirm that the borrower has, or will have, undisputed ownership of the property when the loan is issued.

Text: the characteristics of the property are as they have been represented; and
Interpretation/Simplification: Verify that the property's features match what was stated in the loan application.

Text: the property serving as collateral is appropriately insured at the time of origination and is maintained under the contractual terms of the mortgage.
Interpretation/Simplification: Ensure the collateral property is properly insured when the loan starts and remains insured as per the mortgage terms.

Text: An ADI would typically seek to ensure that property serving as collateral could be readily linked to related residential mortgage lending facilities.
Interpretation/Simplification: The bank should ensure that collateral properties can be easily linked to their corresponding mortgage loans.

Text: Underinvestment in such collateral tracking capability could leave an ADI open to increased operational risks and losses.
Interpretation/Simplification: Insufficient investment in collateral tracking systems can lead to higher operational risks and financial losses for the bank.

Section: Security valuation - Commercial vs. Residential Lending
Text: An ADI would, as a matter of good practice, develop a policy on when a borrower (or connected group of borrowers) providing collateral in the form of mortgages over multiple residential properties is more akin to commercial lending than residential lending.
Interpretation/Simplification: The bank should develop a policy to determine when loans secured by multiple residential properties from a single borrower or group should be classified as commercial lending, not residential.

Section: Security valuation - Commercial vs. Residential Lending
Text: This is particularly the case where one borrower holds multiple housing stock in the same title/deposited plan.
Interpretation/Simplification: This policy is especially relevant when a single borrower owns many properties under the same legal title.

Section: Security valuation - Commercial vs. Residential Lending
Text: In addition, where a developer or commercial borrower chooses to hold a number of residential properties longer term, as opposed to selling them, the risks are more likely to be of a commercial rather than residential nature.
Interpretation/Simplification: If developers or commercial borrowers retain residential properties long-term instead of selling them, the associated risks are more commercial than residential.

Text: Although mortgage lending risk cannot be fully mitigated through conservative LVRs, prudent LVR limits help to minimise the risk that the property serving as collateral will be insufficient to cover any repayment shortfall.
Interpretation/Simplification: While conservative LVRs don't eliminate all mortgage risk, they reduce the chance that collateral won't cover a loan shortfall.

Text: Consequently, prudent LVR limits serve as an important element of portfolio risk management.
Interpretation/Simplification: Well-managed LVR limits are a key component of effective portfolio risk management.

Text: APRA emphasises, however, that loan origination policies would not be expected to be solely reliant on LVR as a risk-mitigating mechanism.
Interpretation/Simplification: Loan origination policies should not rely only on LVRs as the sole method for mitigating risk.

Text: A prudent ADI would monitor exposures by LVR bands over time.
Interpretation/Simplification: The bank should continuously track its loan exposures based on different LVR ranges.

Text: Significant increases in high LVR lending would typically be a trigger for senior management to review risk targets and internal controls over high LVR lending, with Board oversight.
Interpretation/Simplification: A substantial increase in high LVR lending should prompt senior management to review risk targets and internal controls for such loans, with Board supervision.

Text: APRA has not formally defined ‘high LVR lending’, but experience shows that LVRs above 90 per cent (including capitalised LMI premium or other fees) clearly expose an ADI to a higher risk of loss.
Interpretation/Simplification: APRA hasn't formally defined 'high LVR lending', but LVRs over 90% (including capitalized fees) are known to significantly increase a bank's risk of loss.

Text: Lending at low LVRs does not remove the need for an ADI to adhere to sound credit practice or consumer lending obligations.
Interpretation/Simplification: Even for low LVR loans, the bank must still follow robust credit practices and meet consumer lending obligations.

Text: A prudent lender would seek to ensure that a residential mortgage loan has reasonable expectations of being repaid without recourse to the underlying collateral.
Interpretation/Simplification: The bank should aim for residential mortgage loans to be repaid solely from the borrower's income, without needing to seize the collateral.

Text: An overall sound assessment would be based on the borrower’s repayment capacity at the time of loan origination rather than an overriding presumption that the value of collateral will appreciate.
Interpretation/Simplification: Loan assessments must prioritize the borrower's ability to repay at the time of origination, not on the assumption that property values will increase.

Text: ADIs typically require a borrower to provide an initial deposit primarily drawn from the borrower’s own funds. Imposing a minimum ‘genuine savings’ requirement as part of this initial deposit is considered
Interpretation/Simplification: Banks usually require an initial deposit from the borrower's own funds, and a 'genuine savings' requirement for this deposit is considered good practice.

Text: A prudent ADI would have limited appetite for taking into account non-genuine savings, such as gifts from a family member. In such cases, it would be prudent for an ADI to take all reasonable steps to determine whether non-genuine savings are to be repaid by the borrower and, if so, to incorporate these repayments in the serviceability assessment.
Interpretation/Simplification: ADIs should be cautious about counting non-genuine savings (like gifts). If these are to be repaid, the repayment must be included in the borrower's ability-to-pay assessment.

Text: A prudent ADI would exhibit greater caution when relying on collateral values in periods of rapid growth in property prices. It may be appropriate for an ADI to strengthen its LVR constraints or re-assess its risk appetite in markets exhibiting rapid price appreciation.
Interpretation/Simplification: When property prices are rapidly increasing, ADIs must be more cautious about the value of collateral and consider tightening Loan-to-Value Ratio (LVR) limits or adjusting their risk appetite.

Text: Sound credit practice would include recalculating LVRs at the time of any top-up loan and other formal loan increases during the life of the loan. Any subsequent refinancing, including any second mortgage, charge or lien, would also typically result in the calculation of a new LVR at the point of refinancing. Such calculations would be based on appropriate and contemporary property valuations. Further, particular caution would need to be exercised in relation to any draw-down on the equity in the property, especially if the draw-down would increase the current LVR above the level originally agreed. Finally, any significant increase in loan exposure would normally be subject to a full assessment of the borrower’s repayment capacity.
Interpretation/Simplification: LVRs must be recalculated for new top-up loans, formal loan increases, and refinancings, using current property valuations. Extra caution is needed for equity draw-downs that raise LVRs above the original agreement. Any major increase in loan size requires a full re-assessment of the borrower's repayment ability.

Text: In the case of valuation of off-the-plan sales, developer prices might not represent a sustainable resale value. Consequently, in such circumstances, a prudent ADI would make appropriate reductions in the off-the-plan prices in determining LVRs or seek independent professional valuations. Similarly, developer discounts would not be treated as part of the borrower’s deposit for LVR calculation purposes: such discounts reduce the sale price, but do not increase the borrower’s deposit.
Interpretation/Simplification: For 'off-the-plan' sales, ADIs should reduce the developer's price or obtain independent valuations when calculating LVRs, as these prices may not reflect true resale value. Developer discounts cannot be counted as part of the borrower's deposit for LVR calculations.

Text: Where an ADI’s risk appetite allows for higher LVR lending, good practice would provide that the additional risk in this lending would be mitigated by measures such as stronger serviceability-adjusted loan pricing and, in the case of IRB banks, higher expected loss provisions and capital. APRA does not consider the sole use of coverage of loans by LMI as a sufficient control to mitigate high LVR risk.
Interpretation/Simplification: If an ADI offers high LVR loans, the added risk must be reduced through measures like adjusted loan pricing based on serviceability, and for IRB banks, higher loss provisions and capital. Lenders Mortgage Insurance (LMI) alone is not considered enough to manage high LVR risk.

Text: Guarantors
Interpretation/Simplification: This section provides guidance regarding loans involving guarantors.

Text: Although some loans include guarantor relationships, e.g. from a parent of the borrower, to cover shortfalls in minimum deposit requirements, these loans potentially carry a higher risk of default. A prudent ADI would assess the guarantor’s income and conduct independent checks on the creditworthiness of the guarantor, the enforceability of potential claims and the value of any collateral pledged by the guarantor. As with other product types, a prudent ADI would consider the need for appropriate portfolio limits within its risk appetite for such lending.
Interpretation/Simplification: Loans with guarantors, while covering deposit shortfalls, have higher default risk. ADIs must independently check the guarantor’s income, creditworthiness, claim enforceability, and collateral value. Portfolio limits should be set for such lending.

Text: Hardship loans and collections
Interpretation/Simplification: This section provides guidance on how to manage loans where borrowers are experiencing hardship and the associated collection processes.

Text: An ADI would typically formulate policies for dealing with delinquent residential mortgage loans. These policies would assist the ADI to appropriately balance the need to recover as much of the loan as is reasonably achievable with the need to observe the substantial body of law and community expectation as to how troubled borrowers would be treated. APRA’s experience is that reputational risk can be underestimated in such circumstances.
Interpretation/Simplification: ADIs must develop policies for delinquent mortgage loans that balance loan recovery with legal obligations and community expectations for treating troubled borrowers. Reputational risk in these situations should not be underestimated.

Text: An ADI’s risk management framework would typically detail a formal plan for managing the collection process, including for periods where delinquency and loss rates are higher than expected.
Interpretation/Simplification: The ADI's risk management framework must include a formal plan for collections, particularly to handle periods of higher-than-expected delinquency and loss rates.

Text: APRA does not require or expect that an ADI’s management of hardship would focus solely upon rapid resolution and recovery of a defaulted residential mortgage loan. Rather, APRA’s expectation is that an ADI’s policy would strive to maximise its longer-term financial and reputational position, as it addresses hardship among borrowers.
Interpretation/Simplification: APRA expects ADIs' hardship policies to prioritize long-term financial stability and reputation, rather than just rapid recovery of defaulted loans.

Text: ADIs are obliged, under consumer laws and banking codes, to consider hardship variations to credit contracts for borrowers experiencing temporary financial difficulty. Hardship concessions can include a reduction in the interest rate or payment, lengthening of loan maturity, or full or partial deferral (capitalisation) of interest for a temporary period. Failure to comply, particularly where multiple residential mortgage loans may be involved, can carry a heavy cost for an ADI. A prudent ADI would seek to ensure it is fully cognisant of legal obligations in this respect and that such obligations are satisfied. Good practice would include testing and other mechanisms to ensure satisfactory outcomes can be achieved.
Interpretation/Simplification: ADIs must comply with consumer laws and banking codes by considering hardship options (e.g., lower rates, longer terms, payment deferrals) for borrowers in temporary financial difficulty. Non-compliance can be costly. ADIs should be fully aware of and meet these legal duties, using testing to ensure good results.

Text: An ADI would be expected to have a full understanding of the risk profile of hardship loans and to ensure that these risks are appropriately reflected in internal management reporting, provisioning and capital adequacy calculations.
Interpretation/Simplification: ADIs must fully understand the risks associated with hardship loans and ensure these risks are accurately reflected in internal reports, loan loss provisions, and capital adequacy calculations.

Text: Where a residential mortgage loan is in default7, a prudent ADI would usually undertake a full revaluation when assessing the value of the collateral. However, valuations other than a full valuation may be appropriate in limited circumstances, for example, a very low LVR.
Interpretation/Simplification: When a mortgage loan defaults, a full revaluation of the collateral is typically required. Exceptions for less than full revaluation may apply in limited cases, such as very low LVRs.

Text: Upon receiving a notice of hardship from a borrower, or where there is an increased risk of non-payment, an ADI would normally re-assess the borrower’s income, living expenses, assets and liabilities. The ADI would also assess whether the status of the loan is performing or non-performing and whether there is a need to apply provisioning and/or revised capital charges.
Interpretation/Simplification: When notified of hardship or increased non-payment risk, an ADI must re-assess the borrower’s financial situation (income, expenses, assets, liabilities) and determine the loan's status (performing/non-performing), along with any required provisions or capital charges.

Text: It would not be prudent for an ADI to establish long-term capitalisation of principal and interest payments on troubled residential mortgage loans in the expectation that the market value of the mortgaged properties will increase from the current value.
Interpretation/Simplification: ADIs should not capitalize principal and interest payments on troubled mortgage loans over the long term, based on the assumption that property values will increase.

Text: 7 Refer to paragraph 76 of Attachment A of APS 113.
Interpretation/Simplification: This is a cross-reference to paragraph 76 of Attachment A of APS 113 for further information.

Text: APRA expects that an ADI, as part of its credit risk appetite framework, will define its approach to resolving troubled loans, both individually and under conditions where an unusually large number of borrowers are distressed at the same time.
Interpretation/Simplification: ADIs must define their strategy for resolving troubled loans, both individual cases and widespread distress, as part of their credit risk appetite framework.

Text: An ADI following good practice would include a carefully considered collections strategy in its credit risk management framework for residential mortgage lending. The framework could include:
Interpretation/Simplification: ADIs should integrate a comprehensive collections strategy for residential mortgage lending into their credit risk management framework. This framework should include the following elements:

Text: a thorough understanding of the external environment that is used to proactively assess customers at risk of default;
Interpretation/Simplification: The collections strategy needs to include a deep understanding of external market conditions to proactively identify customers who might default.

Text: segmentation of borrowers depending on whether they are willing/not willing and able/not able to repay;
Interpretation/Simplification: Borrowers should be categorized based on their willingness and ability to repay their loans.

Text: adequate training for staff responsible for collection strategies to handle defaulting customers in a sensitive and efficient manner having regard to the ADI’s statutory and contractual rights and obligations;
Interpretation/Simplification: Staff managing collections must receive sufficient training to deal with defaulting customers sensitively and efficiently, always adhering to legal and contractual obligations.

Text: feedback into any risk models the ADI may use to calculate probability of defaults; and
Interpretation/Simplification: Information from collection activities should be integrated into risk models to improve the accuracy of default probability calculations.

Text: appropriate reporting to senior management and the Board on delinquencies, including recoveries and cost of collections.
Interpretation/Simplification: Senior management and the Board must receive regular and appropriate reports on loan delinquencies, including details on recoveries and collection costs.

Text: APRA has observed varying practices with respect to prudential reporting on loans with hardship (or similar payment concessions). Sound practices in this area would include:
Interpretation/Simplification: APRA has noted inconsistent reporting practices for hardship loans. Sound reporting practices for these loans include the following:

Text: arrears would continue to accrue based on the original scheduled payments until the loan is brought back into performing status. For prudential reporting purposes, ADIs would not freeze or re-age loans where hardship (or other similar payment) concessions have been granted;
Interpretation/Simplification: Even with hardship concessions, arrears must continue to accumulate based on the original payment schedule until the loan is performing again. For regulatory reporting, ADIs cannot freeze or re-age loans under hardship.

Text: hardship or collections decisions and activities that include some form of ongoing concession beyond that normally available (non-commercial terms) are required to be reported as ‘restructured items’ in various APRA prudential returns. Non-commerciality is not merely the application of renegotiated ongoing provision of a presumed normal interest charge. It could potentially include longer periods of interest-only lending and/or loan tenors beyond those normally offered for the product and purpose. Non-commercial terms could include agreements to capitalise interest and fees, awaiting property sale or other agreements, consistently renegotiating terms to avoid further collections activity and any ‘pay-what-you-can’ type structures; and
Interpretation/Simplification: Hardship or collection actions that involve concessions beyond normal commercial terms must be reported as ‘restructured items’ in APRA returns. This includes things like extended interest-only periods, longer loan terms, capitalizing interest/fees, or 'pay-what-you-can' arrangements.

Text: appropriate loan-loss collective provisioning for loans subject to hardship applications, given the potentially higher ultimate loss rates on these loans.
Interpretation/Simplification: Adequate collective loan-loss provisions must be made for loans under hardship applications, recognizing their higher potential for ultimate losses.

Text: Stress testing
Interpretation/Simplification: This section provides guidance and requirements for conducting stress tests.

Text: In addition to enterprise–wide stress tests, portfolio-level and risk-specific stress tests of residential mortgage lending portfolios are considered good practice.8
Interpretation/Simplification: Beyond overall enterprise-wide stress tests, ADIs should also perform specific stress tests for their residential mortgage portfolios at both the portfolio and individual risk levels.

Text: A prudent ADI would regularly stress test its residential mortgage lending portfolio under a range of scenarios. Scenarios used for stress testing would include severe but plausible adverse conditions.
Interpretation/Simplification: ADIs must regularly stress test their residential mortgage portfolios using a variety of severe, yet realistic, adverse scenarios.

Text: In developing scenarios, ADIs could benefit from consideration of international experience, as well as domestic experience and previous APRA stress test scenarios to determine what constitutes sufficient severity for such tests. Assumptions around economic growth, unemployment, property prices and interest rates are particularly important in formulating effective scenarios for residential mortgage portfolios. The scenario and modelling assumptions used for stress testing, and the impact of material variations in these assumptions on the results of the stress test, would be communicated to the ADI’s senior management.
Interpretation/Simplification: When creating stress test scenarios, ADIs should consider global and local experiences, including past APRA scenarios, to ensure sufficient severity. Key assumptions (e.g., economic growth, unemployment, property prices, interest rates) are crucial. Senior management must be informed of scenarios, modeling assumptions, and the impact of changes on stress test results.

Text: The complexity and granularity of stress testing would take into account the scale and proportion of an ADI’s residential mortgage lending, and the risk characteristics within it.
