Good practice would be for an ADI to conduct stress testing at a sufficiently granular level to enable adequate sensitivity to the risk characteristics of different loan types. These characteristics would typically include product type, LVR, LMI coverage (including counterparty credit risk), serviceability, geography, vintage, origination channel and borrower characteristics.
Interpretation/Simplification: Stress testing complexity and detail should match the size and risk profile of the ADI's mortgage portfolio. It should be granular enough to capture sensitivities across different loan types, considering factors like product, LVR, LMI, serviceability, geography, and borrower traits.

Text: Results from portfolio stress tests enable the Board and senior management to review an ADI’s risk appetite, capital adequacy and relevant strategic business decisions in both current and potential environments. For example, stress tests might identify vulnerabilities in certain product or borrower segments that would prompt an ADI to tighten its loan origination criteria or lower risk appetite limits on those products.
Interpretation/Simplification: Stress test results help the Board and senior management evaluate risk appetite, capital adequacy, and strategic decisions, potentially leading to stricter loan criteria or reduced risk limits for specific products or borrower groups.

Text: Stress test models would ordinarily be appropriately validated and checked by an independent internal group or by an appropriately qualified external party. Vendor models, where used, would be appropriately customised to the specific risk profile of the ADI. Appropriate systems infrastructure and sound data architecture are central to conducting meaningful residential mortgage lending stress tests.
Interpretation/Simplification: Stress test models must be validated by an independent internal or external group. Any vendor models used need to be tailored to the ADI's specific risk profile. Robust IT systems and data architecture are crucial for effective mortgage lending stress tests.

Text: Stress testing arrangements include well-documented policies and procedures governing the stress testing program, including timely communication of the stress test results to the Board, senior management and other relevant staff. When reporting results, sufficient information would be provided to enable the Board and senior management to understand and challenge stress test assumptions and conclusions. This includes quantitative information on the scenario, results, capital impact, key assumptions and recommended actions arising from the stress tests.
Interpretation/Simplification: Stress testing requires documented policies and procedures, including prompt reporting of results to the Board, senior management, and relevant staff. Reports must contain enough detail (quantitative data, capital impact, assumptions, recommended actions) for them to understand and challenge the stress test findings.

Text: 8 APS 110 requires an ADI to include stress testing and scenario analysis relating to potential risk exposures and available capital resources in its Internal Capital Adequacy Assessment Process (ICAAP). Guidance on the approaches used for stress testing can be found in Prudential Practice Guide CPG 110 Internal Capital Adequacy Assessment Process and Supervisory Review. Prudential Standard APS 110 Capital Adequacy (APS 110) requires ADIs to conduct enterprise-wide stress testing as part of internal capital planning. A core element of enterprise-wide stress testing is the development of loss expectations on material credit exposures, including residential mortgage lending (where relevant).
Interpretation/Simplification: This note refers to APS 110 and CPG 110, which mandate ADIs to incorporate stress testing and scenario analysis into their ICAAP for assessing risk exposures and capital, and to conduct enterprise-wide stress testing for capital planning, including loss expectations for credit exposures.

Text: Lenders mortgage insurance
Interpretation/Simplification: This section provides guidance and requirements related to Lenders Mortgage Insurance (LMI).

Text: LMI is not an alternative to loan origination due diligence. A prudent ADI would, notwithstanding the presence of LMI coverage, conduct its own due diligence, including comprehensive and independent assessment of a borrower’s capacity to repay, verification of minimum initial equity by borrowers, reasonable debt service coverage, and assessment of the value of the property.
Interpretation/Simplification: LMI does not replace an ADI's own due diligence. ADIs must still independently assess a borrower’s repayment capacity, verify initial equity, ensure adequate debt service coverage, and value the property, even if LMI is present.

Text: An ADI needs a clear understanding of the specific requirements of an LMI provider at loan origination, for ongoing monitoring and servicing and for collection actions on loans covered by an LMI provider. An ADI would need to ensure compliance with all LMI requirements to avoid invalidating the cover in the event of a claim. The specific LMI requirements, and the obligations of the ADI, are best reflected in an ADI’s residential mortgage lending risk management framework. Good practice is for internal audit and/or risk management functions to periodically test and confirm an ADI’s compliance with the requirements of an LMI provider.
Interpretation/Simplification: ADIs must clearly understand and comply with LMI provider requirements at loan origination, during ongoing monitoring and servicing, and for collection actions, to avoid invalidating coverage. These requirements should be documented in the ADI’s risk management framework, and compliance should be regularly tested by internal audit or risk management.

Text: Although any review or audit by LMI providers over an ADI’s origination process could be insightful, a prudent ADI would not rely solely on the audit and compliance regimes of LMI providers. APRA expects an ADI to have its own hindsight review and audit regime.
Interpretation/Simplification: While audits by LMI providers can be useful, ADIs must not solely depend on them. APRA expects ADIs to maintain their own independent post-origination review and audit processes.

Text: LMI serves a number of purposes. In particular, it can be used by ADIs as a risk mitigant, to smooth out the normal variability of losses that occurs over time and to diversify regional concentrations of risk. Although LMI is used to protect ADIs by transferring a share of the credit risk on a loan to an LMI provider, residual risks remain. Furthermore, ADI due diligence and other practices may be supplemented or enhanced, but they cannot be replaced by LMI.
Interpretation/Simplification: LMI helps ADIs mitigate risk, smooth out loss variability, and diversify risk concentrations by transferring some credit risk. However, it does not eliminate all risks, and it supplements, but does not replace, an ADI’s own due diligence and practices.

Text: Authorised deposit-taking institution as defined in the Banking Act 1959.
Interpretation/Simplification: An ADI is a financial institution authorized to take deposits, as defined by Australian banking law.

Text: A system or process that can provide an estimate of real estate property valuations using mathematical modelling, taking account of relevant factors, combined with a database.
Interpretation/Simplification: AVM is a technology-driven system that estimates property values using data and algorithms, without human physical inspection.

Text: An organisation that maintains consumer credit data files and provides credit information to authorised users, such as credit providers, usually for a fee.
Interpretation/Simplification: An organization (like Experian or Equifax) that collects and shares individuals' credit histories with approved lenders.

Text: Proportion of delinquent loans (usually mortgages or other retail loans) that exit that condition over a period of time by being brought current or repaid.
Interpretation/Simplification: The percentage of loans that were previously behind on payments but are now up-to-date or fully paid off.

Text: An authority, e.g. a lending officer or committee that can approve a loan (based on product, amount, risk grade or other risk characteristics). The authority is usually linked to the seniority or experience of the officer or committee. Also known as delegated credit authority, credit discretions or similar.
Interpretation/Simplification: The power given to a specific individual or team, often based on their experience, to approve loans within certain limits or criteria.

Text: Percentage of loans that are in default over their contractual payments.
Interpretation/Simplification: The proportion of loans where borrowers have failed to make payments as agreed in their contract.

Text: A method of assessment that does not involve a physical inspection of the residential property.
Interpretation/Simplification: A property assessment or valuation done remotely, without a valuer physically visiting the property.

Text: The proportion of a borrower’s income that is used to service the borrower’s debt obligations.
Interpretation/Simplification: The percentage of a person's gross income that is allocated to paying off their debts.

Text: A loan with a floating or variable interest rate. Also known as a variable rate loan.
Interpretation/Simplification: A loan product where the interest rate can change over the life of the loan, typically in response to market rates.

Text: Financial Stability Board
Interpretation/Simplification: FSB stands for Financial Stability Board.

Text: Household Expenditure Measure
Interpretation/Simplification: HEM refers to the Household Expenditure Measure, a benchmark for typical household living expenses.

Text: A line of credit based on the amount of equity built up in a borrower’s property. As the loan is repaid the money becomes available for re-use.
Interpretation/Simplification: A HELOC is a flexible loan that uses your home's equity as collateral, allowing you to borrow, repay, and re-borrow funds up to an approved limit.

Text: Henderson Poverty Index
Interpretation/Simplification: HPI stands for Henderson Poverty Index, a measure of poverty.

Text: A loan on which only interest is paid during the loan term. The loan may revert to principal and interest repayments at the end of the loan term. The term is usually for a period of one to five years, although it may extend longer.
Interpretation/Simplification: A loan type where for an initial period, only interest payments are required, with principal repayments starting later.

Text: An exterior assessment by a valuer to confirm the location and observable condition of a property, used particularly for further advances on an existing mortgage and/or if house prices have not fluctuated significantly. The valuer will often draw on comparisons with properties recently sold in the area to support his/her estimation.
Interpretation/Simplification: A property valuation performed by observing the property's exterior from the street, often supplemented by comparing it to recent local sales.

Text: Lenders’ mortgage insurance has its ordinary commercial meaning and includes insurance under a policy that protects a lender from losses in the event of borrower default on a loan secured by a mortgage over residential or other property.
Interpretation/Simplification: LMI is an insurance policy that protects the mortgage lender from financial loss if a borrower defaults on their loan.

Text: Process by which a lender determines whether and under what conditions to make a loan.
Interpretation/Simplification: The entire process a financial institution undertakes to decide whether to approve a loan application and under what terms.

Text: Identification of a loan, typically for risk analysis, based on the year in which a loan was originated.
Interpretation/Simplification: Refers to categorizing loans by the year they were issued, primarily for analyzing their performance and risk over time.

Text: The ratio of the amount of the loan outstanding to the value of the property securing the loan.
Interpretation/Simplification: LVR is a percentage that compares the amount of a loan to the appraised value of the asset (usually property) securing the loan.

Text: The total balance of mortgage repayments that have been paid ahead of their due date.
Interpretation/Simplification: The accumulated amount of extra mortgage payments made by a borrower beyond what was scheduled, creating a 'buffer'.

Text: The net income available to a borrower after taxes, living expenses and financial commitments.
Interpretation/Simplification: The money a borrower has remaining after all necessary deductions, including taxes, living costs, and debt payments.

Text: A valuation made on the basis of a development plan, not on the basis of the finished property. The valuer/purchaser may be able to view a display unit and sample finishes.
Interpretation/Simplification: An assessment of a property's value based on its proposed design and plans before it has been fully built.

Text: Approval of a loan that is outside an ADI’s lending policy.
Interpretation/Simplification: Granting an exception to a bank's standard lending rules to approve a loan that would otherwise be rejected.

Text: Prudential practice guide
Interpretation/Simplification: PPG refers to a Prudential Practice Guide, which provides guidance on sound financial practices.

Text: A mortgage that allows a borrower to borrow money using equity in his/her home as security. The loan may be taken as a lump sum, a regular income stream, a line of credit or a combination of these options. Interest is charged as for any other loan, except no repayments are made while the person lives in the home. Interest compounds over time and is added to the loan balance. The loan is repayable in full (including interest and fees) when the person sells the home, dies or moves into aged care.
Interpretation/Simplification: A loan for homeowners (typically seniors) that converts home equity into cash. No monthly payments are required until the homeowner sells, moves out, or passes away, at which point the loan is repaid from the sale of the home.

Text: An automated tool for assessing borrower risk that aids a lender in the granting of consumer credit.
Interpretation/Simplification: An automated system used by lenders to evaluate the creditworthiness and risk level of potential borrowers for consumer loans.

Text: Self-managed superannuation fund
Interpretation/Simplification: SMSF stands for Self-Managed Superannuation Fund, a private superannuation fund that you manage yourself.
